paragraphs.content: The imperfect is, together with the present perfect, one of the most used past tenses in Italian. It is called ‘imperfect’ because, generally speaking, there is no reference to the beginning or end of the action it expresses: either the length of time the action lasted is not relevant, or the action is seen as the background to another action, or two actions took place at the same time and lasted the same length of time. Here are some typical examples:

rows: My grandfather used to work in India.
As I was going in, Elena was coming out.
Quando ho cominciato la scuola **avevo** cinque anni.
When I started school I was five.
Elena arrived as I was going out.
Claudia **parlava** con un’amica quando è arrivato l’autobus.
Claudia was talking to a friend when the bus arrived.
Quando **ero** al mare **nuotavo** tutti i giorni.
When I was at the seaside I went/used to go swimming every day.

paragraphs.content: As you can see from the examples, the Italian imperfect corresponds to several different English forms. We will look at the different meanings and uses of this tense, but first we will look at its forms.
The forms of the imperfect are very regular. Here are the endings for the three conjugations (**-are**, **-ere**, **-ire**):
All verbs ending in **-urre** have the following pattern:

rows: Quando ero bambino abitavo a Parma.
When I was a child I lived in Parma.
Al concerto c’erano più di 900 persone.
There were more than 900 people at the concert.
Mia sorella beveva solo acqua minerale, ora beve anche acqua di rubinetto.
My sister only used to drink mineral water, now she drinks tap water as well.
Cosa faceva, Signora, quando non lavorava?
What did you do(, Madam), when you weren’t working/didn’t work?
The interpreter was translating, but nobody was listening.

paragraphs.content: The negative is formed, as usual, by putting **non** before the verb:

rows: Di solito la domenica non uscivo.
I didn’t usually go out on Sundays.
Quando hai telefonato non facevo niente di speciale.
When you phoned I wasn’t doing anything special.

paragraphs.content: The imperfect is used for descriptions of situations in the past, when it is not necessary (or important) to say how long an action lasted. This generally happens with verbs like essere, sembrare and avere, and with verbs expressing will, desire or intention, possibility or ability; but it can happen with other verbs as well:

rows: C’erano molte persone che aspettavano il treno.
There were a lot of people (who were) waiting for the train.
You looked very tired last night.
Mia nonna era molto alta e aveva i capelli bianchi.
My grandmother was very tall and had white hair.
Was it cold in the mountains?
What did you want/were you wanting?
Due anni fa abitavo a Milano.
Two years ago I was living in Milan.

paragraphs.content: The imperfect is also used to express actions which were habitual or hap￾pened repeatedly in the past:

rows: L’estate scorsa giocavamo sempre a tennis.
Last summer we played tennis all the time.
Quando ero in vacanza andavo al cinema tutti i giorni.
When I was on holiday I went to the cinema every day.
Tutte le mattine a colazione Giulia prendeva solo del caffè.
Every morning Giulia just had coffee for breakfast.
We used to have dinner at eight.

paragraphs.content: Since the imperfect is used when it is not relevant how long the action lasted, it is not used when it is stated how many times, or for how long, something happened:

rows: L’estate scorsa sono andato al cinema 25 volte
Last summer I went to the cinema 25 times.
Ha fatto molto freddo per due giorni.
It was very cold for two days.
Giulia ha lavorato qui da gennaio a giugno.
Giulia worked here from January to June.
Ho abitato a Milano per due anni.
I lived in Milan for two years.
Ieri abbiamo lavorato tutto il giorno.
Ieri sono stato in biblioteca dalle nove alle undici.
Yesterday I was in the library from nine till 11.

paragraphs.content: When a sentence refers to two or more events which happened in the past, it is helpful to think in terms of ‘foreground’ and ‘background’, as in these two English examples: ‘While I was doing the dishes [continuous background], I heard [foreground] the doorbell’; ‘I saw [foreground] Juve a couple of times when I was [continuous background] in Turin’. In Italian, in cases like these, the imperfect expresses the continuous ‘background’ action against which the ‘foreground’ action is seen to occur:

rows: Mentre* dormivate ho preparato la colazione.
While you were sleeping/asleep I prepared breakfast.
Mia madre ha conosciuto mio padre quando abitava a Firenze.
My mother met my father when she was living in Florence.
Mauro non ha preso l’ombrello anche se pioveva.
Mauro didn’t take the umbrella even though it was raining.
Marco ha telefonato quando eravate al cinema.
Marco phoned when you were at the cinema.
I didn’t go out because it was raining.

paragraphs.content: * Note that **mentre** (while), in the past, is always followed by the imperfect.
If the two events happened at the same time and lasted for the same length of time, then both verbs are in the imperfect:

rows: Mentre noi facevamo il compito di matematica, Carla ripassava filosofia.
While we were doing our maths homework, Carla was revising philosophy.
Mentre Alessandro preparava la cena, Claudia leggeva il giornale.
While Alessandro was preparing dinner, Claudia was reading the newspaper.
Quando io lavoravo al supermercato, mia sorella lavorava in un cinema.
When I worked in the supermarket, my sister worked in a cinema.
Il gatto miagolava perché aveva fame.
The cat was miaowing because it was hungry.

exercises.title: Exercise 1
exercises.instruction: Supply the imperfect of the verb in brackets.

items.question: Il nonno di Piero (parlare) sei lingue.
Laura (passare) sempre l’estate al mare.
Che lavoro (fare) tua nonna?
Mentre (io studiare), Maria (riposare).
Il treno (partire) sempre in ritardo.
Dove (lavorare) Nicola?
Paolo non (dire) mai la verità.
Ieri (fare) freddo.
Da bambini (noi abitare) in campagna.
(voi essere) stanchi ieri sera?
(loro andare) in piscina tutti i giorni.
Lei (essere) infermiera, Signora?
Non (noi uscire) mai di domenica.
(tu sapere) la verità?
(io conoscere) bene suo cugino.
Paolo (amare) Francesca.
(voi dormire) ancora?
I miei amici (essere) studenti.
(tu avere) fame?
(loro dovere) partire.

exercises.instruction: Supply the correct tense (**present perfect** or **imperfect**) of the verb in brackets.
examples: Elena, a che ora (**tu partire**) ieri?: Elena, a che ora **sei partita** ieri?
Chi (**essere**) Dante Alighieri?: Chi **era** Dante Alighieri?

items.question: Elena, a che ora (tu partire) ieri?
Chi (essere) Dante Alighieri?
(io studiare) per due ore.
Di solito (noi mangiare) in mensa.
Claudia (rimanere) in casa tutto il giorno.
Mia nonna (avere) gli occhi azzurri.
Nicoletta e Luigina non (sembrare) sorelle.
Ieri Andrea (spendere) 150 euro.
Signora, dove (andare) in vacanza l’anno scorso?

exercises.title: Exercise 3
exercises.instruction: Supply the correct tense (present perfect or imperfect) of the verb in brackets.
examples: Mentre (noi guardare) la televisione Isabella (ascoltare) la radio: guardavamo, ascoltava

items.question: Marco (arrivare) tardi perché il treno (essere) in ritardo
(io conoscere) Susanna quando (io abitare) a Napoli.

Sergio (telefonare) proprio mentre (io fare) il bagno.

exercises.title: Exercise 4
exercises.instruction: Put the text into a past tense, changing the verbs in italics to either the present perfect or the imperfect.

items.question: Sabato sera in un locale del centro *suona* un gruppo rock che *piace* molto a Massimo, così i miei amici e io *decidiamo* di andare a questo concerto.
*Arriviamo* davanti al locale con molto anticipo: *mancano* tre ore all’inizio, ma *ci sono* già molte persone.
Massimo è molto impaziente.
Dopo una mezz’ora, mentre *aspettiamo*, *sentiamo* suonare il cellulare di Massimo e lui *risponde*.
*Vediamo* che Massimo *è* preoccupato e quando *finisce* di parlare ci *spiega*.
items.answer: abbiamo visto, era, ha finito, ha spiegato

items.question: *È* suo padre che lo *chiama* perché *ha* bisogno di aiuto: la sua auto *è* guasta e non *sa* come tornare a casa.
Massimo *parte* subito per andare a prenderlo e accompagnarlo a casa anche se *ha* paura di perdere il concerto.
Per fortuna, però, Massimo *riesce* a tornare dopo un’ora, proprio mentre *aprono* le porte.
How long did you [sing.] spend in Bologna?
items.answer: Quanto tempo hai passato a Bologna?

items.question: We went to the cinema last night.
answer: Siamo andati al cinema ieri sera.
Siamo andate al cinema ieri sera.

items.question: You [pl.] seemed happy.
Gemma’s father was a sailor.
answer: Il padre di Gemma faceva il marinaio.
Il padre di Gemma era marinaio.

items.question: Claudia and Monica didn’t come on holiday with us this time.
items.answer: Claudia e Monica non sono venute in vacanza con noi questa volta.

items.question: My parents usually went out at eight.
items.answer: I miei genitori di solito uscivano alle otto.

items.question: My father worked in India for three years.
items.answer: Mio padre lavorava in India per tre anni.

items.question: What time did you [pl.] get the bus yesterday morning?
items.answer: A che ora avete preso l’autobus ieri mattina?

items.question: Last year we did gym on Monday mornings.
answer: L’anno scorso facevamo ginnastica il lunedì mattina.
L’anno scorso facevamo ginnastica di lunedì mattina.

items.question: Where did you [sing.] buy those shoes?
I didn’t call you [sing.] because you were asleep.
answer: Non ti ho chiamato perché dormivi.
Non ti ho chiamata perché dormivi.

items.question: When you [pl.] were living in London, I was living in Paris.
answer: Quando voi abitavate a Londra io abitavo a Parigi.
Quando voi vivevate a Londra io abitavo a Parigi.
Quando voi abitavate a Londra io vivevo a Parigi.
Quando voi vivevate a Londra io vivevo a Parigi.

items.question: How old was Susanna when she went to university?
items.answer: Quanti anni aveva Susanna quando è andata all’università?

items.question: While I was watching the television, Anna came in and switched it off.
items.answer: Mentre guardavo la televisione, Anna è entrata e l’ha spenta.

items.question: Paolo and Giulia didn’t come because Paolo was too tired.
items.answer: Paolo e Giulia non sono venuti perché Paolo era troppo stanco.
